name: Hedetniemi's conjecture
rephrased: The chromatic number of the tensor product of two graphs is equal to the minimum chromatic number of the two graphs.
implication_form: If P and Q are graphs, then the chromatic number of their tensor product is equal to the minimum of their individual chromatic numbers.
explained: Hedetni'tniemi's conjecture, proposed by Stephen T. Hedetniemi in 1966, addresses the chromatic number of the tensor product of two graphs. It claims that the chromatic number of the product graph G × H is exactly equal to the minimum of the chromatic numbers of the individual graphs G and H. In mathematical notation: χ(G × H) = min{χ(G), χ(H)}.
terms: Tensor product of graphs (also called categorical product)
related_conjectures: The tensor product coloring problem (which is the conjecture itself)
The conjecture regarding the chromatic number of the tensor product of complete graphs (χ(K_m × K_n) = min{m,n} for all m,n ≥ 1)
